newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian bond yields spike, wary eye on N.Z..
newsitem.headline: Australian bond yields spike, wary eye on N.Z..

text.p: *Australian bonds yields spiked higher in early trading reflecting pre-weekend profit-taking after the strong rally over the past two days and amid concerns over the New Zealand market.
*Market to remain underpinned by expected favourable CPI.
Australian bonds yields spiked higher in early trading on Friday reflecting pre-weekend profit-taking after the strong rally over the past two days and amid concerns over the New Zealand market.
"The kiwi market is getting smashed. While that could generate some switching activity, at the moment the market is concerned about a spillover to here," one trader said.

The New Zealand dollar dropped one U.S. cent to a 19-month low as a large U.S. hedge fund hit the market, prompting a sharp rise in debt yields in attempt to bring monetary conditions to the RBNZ's desired level.
A softer bias in U.S. Treasuries also weighed on the market.
However, traders said any local sell-off is likely to be restrained with the market underpinned by expectations of a benign outcome to next week's second quarter inflation data.
The September 10-year bond futures contract had struck a new 3-1/2 year high of 93.510 in after hours trading, nearing the all time high of 93.630, before the market slithered back.

Meanwhile, former Reserve Bank governor Bernie Fraser is due to address a conference in Melbourne about 1.40 p.m. (0340 GMT) and the market will be closely watching for any mention of current monetary conditions.

The local market underperformed against both the U.S. and Canada, but spreads tightened to a weak N.Z. market. Profit-taking in the U.S. stunted an early advance, while the Canadian market was hit by a fall in the Canadian dollar.
